conversation_id: "689d1b92-77c8-8328-82c9-4257cee9f472" title: "Stop GRID charges" accounts: ["Account1_exports"] models: [] tags: [] message_count: 106

Stop GRID charges

system

system

2025-08-13T23:12:04.932642Z user

{"content_type": "image_asset_pointer", "asset_pointer": "file-service://file-EUYyryR451ixvCzQYQ5Smv", "size_bytes": 109718, "width": 720, "height": 1604, "fovea": null, "metadata": {"dalle": null, "gizmo": null, "generation": null, "container_pixel_height": null, "container_pixel_width": null, "emu_omit_glimpse_image": null, "emu_patches_override": null, "lpe_keep_patch_ijhw": null, "sanitized": true, "asset_pointer_link": null, "watermarked_asset_pointer": null}} How do I get fucking grid to stop fucking my credit file up? They continuously try to charge my cards I've told them to stop and reported them as fraudulent and they're the ONLY missed payments on my file

2025-08-13T23:12:05.046397Z assistant

2025-08-13T23:12:05.130952Z assistant

It looks like GRID is still able to bill you and because those charges arent being paid, theyre hitting your credit report as late payments. Since theyre the only negative marks on your file, stopping them at the source and getting them removed should be your top priority.

Heres the step-by-step route Id take:

1. Shut Off Their Access to Your Cards

  • Call your bank or card issuer directly and tell them to block all future charges from GRID (give them the merchant name and any transaction IDs).
  • If the bank cant block them, close the card and request a new number.
  • Make sure you remove the card from any GRID account (even if its inactive).

2. Send a Cease and Desist + Revocation of Authorization

  • Write GRID a letter or email saying:
    • You revoke all authorization for future charges.
    • Any further charges will be treated as fraud.
  • Keep proof of this (email receipts, certified mail).

3. Dispute Past Charges

  • With your bank: File a fraud or billing error dispute for every unwanted charge.
  • With the credit bureaus: Dispute the late payments, providing proof that you withdrew authorization and reported the transactions as fraudulent.

4. File Consumer Complaints

  • CFPB (Consumer Financial Protection Bureau) cfpb.gov/complaint
  • FTC (Federal Trade Commission) reportfraud.ftc.gov
  • State Attorney Generals office often effective for getting a company to stop.

5. Document Everything

  • Keep copies of every call log, email, letter, and dispute.
  • Note dates, times, and names of representatives you speak with.

If you want, I can draft you a credit bureau dispute letter and a CFPB complaint that clearly shows GRIDs charges are unauthorized and should be removed from your report. That will maximize your chances of getting those 3 late payments erased entirely.

Do you want me to prep those templates so you can send them today?

2025-08-13T23:12:05.191330Z system

2025-08-13T23:12:59.936266Z user

I wish you could just go attack the whole thing for me lmao

2025-08-13T23:13:00.064478Z assistant

Trust me, if I could just storm the gates of GRID HQ with a digital battering ram and wipe those late payments off your file myself, Id be there in under a millisecond.

Since Im stuck in the advisor lane instead of the cyber-SWAT lane, the next best thing is to hand you a battle plan that makes them regret ever putting a toe near your credit file.

I can:

  • Write you a CFPB + FTC complaint in your voice so it hits hard but stays professional.

If your goal is to channel that 20-mile march endurance without wrecking your joints, Id go:

1 For Endurance & Mental Grind Treadmill

  • Set a steady pace (34 mph) at a moderate incline (36%) to mimic field terrain.
  • Do longer sessions (4590 min) a few times a week.
  • Throw in a weighted vest (start light, 1015 lbs) once youre comfortable simulates gear without hammering your knees like asphalt does.

2 For Strength & Marching With Gear Power Stair Climber

  • Great for building the leg/glute endurance that makes real marches easier.
  • Shorter sessions (1530 min) are brutal but effective.
  • If you alternate stair days with treadmill days, your endurance and power go up fast.

Best plan:
Alternate them.

  • Treadmill days for mileage, pacing, and mental zone training.
  • Stair days for power and that uphill with a pack burn.

Alright heres your 6-Week Modern March Program for Planet Fitness.
Its designed to give you the endurance of a 20-mile ruck march and the leg strength to carry gear, without trashing your joints.

Weeks 12: Foundation Phase

Goal: Build base endurance and get used to consistent sessions.

3 Days Treadmill March

  • Speed: 3.03.5 mph
  • Incline: 35%
  • Duration: 45 min (steady pace)
  • Optional: Light 510 lb weighted vest by the end of week 2.

2 Days Stair Climber

  • Level: 46 (easy/moderate)
  • Duration: 1015 min (continuous, no hands on rails)
  • Focus on steady breathing and posture.

Weeks 34: Load & Elevation Phase

Goal: Start simulating gear weight and tougher terrain.

3 Days Treadmill March

  • Speed: 3.33.8 mph
  • Incline: 58%
  • Duration: 5060 min
  • Weighted vest: 1015 lbs (use a plate carrier or sandbag vest for comfort).

2 Days Stair Climber

  • Level: 68 (moderate challenge)
  • Duration: 1520 min
  • Add 23 bursts of 1 min at higher level (810) mid-session.

Weeks 56: Combat-Ready Phase

Goal: Max endurance + power without injury.

3 Days Treadmill March

  • Speed: 3.54.0 mph
  • Incline: 812% (start low, increase weekly)
  • Duration: 6075 min
  • Weighted vest: 1520 lbs (break in slowly).

2 Days Stair Climber

  • Level: 810 (moderate-hard)
  • Duration: 2025 min
  • Every 5 min, do a 1-min sprint at Level 1214.

Extra Notes:

  • Stretch calves, hamstrings, and hips after every session.
  • Stay hydrated bring at least a 20 oz water bottle for treadmill sessions over 45 min.
  • If anything starts aching in the knees or lower back, drop the weight until it passes.
  • Once you finish 6 weeks, you can either repeat with higher inclines/weight or shift to outdoor hikes.

2025-08-14T00:40:05.735101Z user

It's my posture I think. My right foot always hurts right where it's hurting. Across the top where my arch should be inner top side of foot

2025-08-14T00:40:06.057261Z assistant

Yeah pain across the inner top side of the foot near where the arch starts is often tied to posture, gait, and how youre loading that foot, especially if its your dominant leg for balance.

A few common culprits:

  • Collapsed arch / overpronation Your foot rolls inward with each step, putting stress on those top tendons.
  • Tight calves & hamstrings Pull your posture slightly forward, loading the foot unevenly.
  • Uneven stride If you always lead or push off harder with that foot, it takes more strain.

Quick fixes to try:

  1. Adjust Treadmill Incline Youre already at 5%, but try dropping to 3% next time and see if it eases the load.
  2. Focus on Neutral Foot Strike Land mid-foot, not heel-first or too much on the inside edge.
  3. Arch Support Even a cheap gel insole with firm arch support can take strain off the top of the foot.
  4. Post-walk stretch Pull toes back toward shin (standing calf stretch), hold 30 sec per side, then roll a frozen water bottle under your arch for 23 min.

If you want, I can give you a gait check drill you can do in under 2 minutes before each treadmill session so you start with the right posture and load distribution. That way youre fixing the root cause, not just managing the pain.

2025-08-14T00:40:58.305830Z user

Lower grade is actually worse

2025-08-14T00:40:58.462363Z assistant

Yeah, that actually makes sense lower grade can feel easier on your lungs, but it changes the angle of your stride so your foot is flexing more at the arch/top with each step.

On a higher grade (like your 5%), youre more forward-leaning and loading the glutes/quads, which takes some stress off the top of the foot.
On a flatter surface, your toes lift higher on each step (dorsiflexion), which can aggravate that inner-top-arch area if those tendons are already sensitive.

If 5% feels better, Id keep it there but:

  • Shorten stride slightly keeps you from over-flexing the foot at push-off.
  • Drop speed by 0.10.2 mph when fatigue sets in so you dont start compensating with bad form.
  • Make sure your shoes arent laced too tight over that spot thats a sneaky cause of top-foot pain.

If you want, I can give you a lacing pattern that takes pressure off the top of your foot entirely while still locking your heel in. That way the incline work doesnt aggravate it.
